greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Factorial base representation of n is rewritten as a base-2 number with each nonzero digit k replaced by a run of k 1's (followed by one extra zero if not the rightmost run of 1's) and with each 0 kept as 0.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..5040
Index entries for sequences related to binary expansion of n
Index entries for sequences related to factorial base representation
formula: A000035(a(n)) = A000035(n). [Preserves the parity of n.]
example: 9 = "111" in factorial base (3! + 2! + 1! = 9) is converted to three 1-bits with separating zeros between, in binary as "10101" = A007088(21), thus a(9) = 21.

91 = "3301" in factorial base (91 = 3*4! + 3*3! + 1!) is converted to binary number "1110111001" = A007088(953), thus a(91) = 953. Between the rightmost 1-runs the other zero comes from the factorial base representation, while the other zero is an extra separating zero inserted after each run of 1-bits apart from the rightmost 1-run. The single zero between the two leftmost 1-runs is similarly used to separate the two "unary representations" of 3's.
program: (define (A277012 n) (let loop ((n n) (z 0) (i 2) (j 0)) (if (zero? n) z (let ((d (remainder n i))) (loop (quotient n i) (+ z (* (A000225 d) (A000079 j))) (+ 1 i) (+ 1 j d))))))
xref: Cf. A277008 (terms sorted into ascending order).
Differs from analogous A277022 for the first time at n=24, where a(24) = 8, while A277022(24) = 60.
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Sep 25 2016
